Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Deep and stable snowpack despite 3" of SWE the previous 5 days.

Graupel layer combined with a wind slab above and the rain crust below could work as weak layer and be an issue in specific wind loaded slopes. The Nov. IFrc/Dec. FC combo doesn't seem to be active in this specific area at this particular elevation. The high temperature gradient in the top pack could lead to a faceting process in the top layers, especially at the IFrc interface.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown profile location was 30' from the trigger point. Weak layer involved was a combination of surface hoar and near surface facets buried by a storm over New Year's. This avalanche was triggered on Feb.3 on the skin track by the 9th and 10th people to ascend the route. No one caught or injured.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: SE facing slope but shaded by mature trees for part of the day. Surprised to see facets this week on a SE facing slope but I think it was a function of the shade from the big trees.

Obvious layers of weak facets. I did a cross slope PST when my ECT did not break at all. It was a steep slope, so this does not work as well as it would on a flatter slope or doing a proper PST....but it did propagate across and I suspect a regular PST would have propagated to the end after a 30-40 cm cut. Just speculation though.

Pit_Observation.activities: Cracking; Recent activity on different slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Upper 4" of storm slab very reactive to ski cuts on rollovers, especially where there is slight wind effect. Ski triggered D1 storm slabs. Otherwise good stability in this pit. Possible previous skier track/traffic down 40-60cm.

Pit_Observation.activities: Snowmobile tracks on slope; We snowmobiled slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Similar test results in several other places. Surface hoar at 76.2 is unreactive. Seems to be healing slightly and the slab above it has changed a lot. With continued warm weather it may be shallow enough to heal. Deeper facets remain a concern if we get a load. They are still incredibly weak and you sink into them easily.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug pit just above cabin and mine dump. Skied in the area. Persistent/Wind Slab problems on N-E near and and above TL in specific terrain features. Stubborn with ski pressure near TL in isolated terrain features. Negative cracking /collapsing on entire route. D1+ potential in area skied due to isolated nature of the slab. Many areas faceted from T to B. HS: 75-100 cms Nth > 11.4k feet.

Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 14 degrees warmer at nearby snotel site than 24 hrs earlier, snow settled 2" in 24 hours.

Lots of roller balls and loose wet sluff on all aspects due to the warm temps. Buried surface hoar layer at 120cm still has cause for concern. Grains seemed to be starting to heal, but still a little reactive in tests. Did not propagate more then a few CM's on ECTN25, but propagated the rest of the way across and came out high energy with some hits on the other side of the column after test completion.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: CT and ECT sheared on bottom of melt-freeze crust. Burp-the-baby showed planar interface at 88, but not very reactive.

Two recent natural avalanches (night before) were seen at the non-operating Teton Pass Ski Resort. Both were East aspect, 38-40 degree start zones and crown depth appeared to be 10-20 inches. The main chute (Pipeline) ran into Moondance and made it to the road (SS-N-R2D2-I), and also Joe's Wave ran in the steepest start zone (40 degrees) and deposited snow just above the Waterfall (SS-N-R2D2-I).

Many hidden rocks just below soft snow surface.

Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Ski tracks on slope
Snowmobile tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This is nearly due south facing. I was surprised by the snow depth and seeing some of the facets...but this is a cold place, so maybe no surprise.

Step off the sled and you sink to the ground. It's amazing how there's just enough supportability for the sleds to stay on top. ECTX because the snowpack just crumbles beneath the shovel. In this sheltered spot, it's weak but stable. Add wind-loading and it becomes unstable fast.

At this elevation, the persistent deep layer seems to be healing and starting to bond. Could not initiate failure using standard testing methods. Did not dig below this layer.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit close to Beaver Boundary rope-line, Ted's Rock Area north of Marge's Lift.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, widespread; Cracking
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Along the entire ascent route leading up to our pit location we experienced widespread collapsing with some cracking.Winds were calm with the occasional gust at the location of the pit. 300 feet above the pit along the Pre Laurel Peak ridgeline the winds were moderate with the occasional gust in to the strong range. Transporting snow from the North half to the south half of the compass. From the Pre Laurel Ridge we experienced out largest collapse of the day. We had just come out on to the ridge above treeline. Walked across the flat terrain above the Coyote Chutes and felt and heard a loud collapse. Likely a more dense slab above the old snow from wind effect. Although, we did not see any cracking associated with this collapse, and it did not remotely trigger Coyote. From Prelude our pit location we wanted to see what the North Woods looked like, so we made the call to exit there in to Gold Basin. Not a good idea. The North Woods needs a minimum of 3 feet of snow before that we will be skiing without fear.
As anticipated additional snow from 20180119 further compounded how reactive the basil facet layer is. Low Mod - Considerable.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: PST failure at 40 cm initiated secondary failure at 66 cm layer. Unexpected test result resulted in closer scrutiny, where I later identified the SH layer. The SH layer was fragile, but it was partially fused due to melt freeze cycle - First time ever I see fused SH!

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Collapsing, widespread; Cracking; Recent activity on similar slopes; Recent activity on different slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug above (20-30 feet) previous avalanche crown from 12-14 days ago, which was mostly filled in. When first person left the pit up the same track we descended on, the entire slope collapsed 100'+ wide. Failed on facets below crust. Big collapse. Deep.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; Snowmobile tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snowpack is full of facets. Surface hoar on the surface but it is laying flat and not a concern. The surface snow is very warm. Many of the faceted layers seem to be rounding a little bit. With the right load, it will find the right layer to make an avalanche, but today was the first where I saw a glimmer of hope for our snowpack. Drew said that I was seeing a mirage - he's probably right. It's wishful thinking.
Warm week leading up to a warm study day. Blue skies and a nice mountain day.
